DOCNAME: CASE OF SABEUR BEN ALI v. MALTA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 5-3;Violation of Art. 5-4;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in GPE for drug - related offences . On DATE he was brought before ORG , composed by a single magistrate , to be arraigned . He was charged with possession of drugs that were not intended for personal use , importation of drugs , conspiracy to commit drug - related offences and various breaches of the customs legislation . In accordance with section CARDINAL of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance , the applicant was remitted to custody pending the conclusion of the criminal inquiry .

CARDINAL . On conclusion of the inquiry on CARDINAL DATE , the applicant was committed for trial . On DATE he applied to ORG for provisional release relying on the fact that “ he ha(d ) been under arrest for a considerable time ” and that “ he ( was ) in a position to give the guarantees required to appear for any part of the proceedings and the trial , as ORG ( might ) order ” . The application was communicated to the Attorney General who was given TIME to reply . After the observations of the Attorney General had been obtained , a magistrate heard the parties on CARDINAL DATE . On DATE the magistrate rejected the application because he was not satisfied that , if the applicant was released , there would be no interference with the due administration of justice .
CARDINAL . The trial commenced on DATE . On DATE the applicant was acquitted of all charges and was released from custody .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW of GPE provides :
“ Any person who is arrested or detained -
( a ) for the purpose of bringing him before a ORG in execution of the order of a ORG ; or
( b ) upon reasonable suspicion of his having committed , or being about to commit , a criminal offence ,

and who is not released , shall be brought not later than TIME before a Court , and if any person arrested or detained in such a case as mentioned in paragraph ( b ) of this subsection is not tried within a reasonable time , then , without prejudice to any further proceedings which may be brought against him , he shall be released either unconditionally or upon reasonable conditions , including in particular such conditions as are reasonably necessary to ensure that he appears at a later date for trial or for proceedings preliminary to trial . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides :

“ CARDINAL . Every officer of ORG below the rank of inspector shall , on securing the person arrested , forthwith report the arrest to an officer not below the rank of inspector who , if he finds sufficient grounds for the arrest , shall order the person arrested to be brought before ORG ; otherwise he shall release him .
CARDINAL . Where an order is given for the person arrested to be brought before ORG , such order shall be carried into effect without any undue delay and shall in no case be deferred beyond TIME . ”

CARDINAL . NORP In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in the PERSON case , ORG of GPE upheld a decision taken by ORG , in the exercise of its constitutional jurisdiction , on DATE to the effect that LAW did not impose any obligation on the magistrate before whom an arrested person appeared to examine whether that person ’s arrest had been made on a reasonable suspicion or not . Moreover , according to the judgment of ORG , as upheld by ORG , Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Convention did not impose on the prosecution any duty , on presenting the arrested person , to adduce evidence that the police had a reasonable suspicion at the time of the arrest .
CARDINAL . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in the PERSON case , ORG followed the same approach .
CARDINAL . The Criminal Code contains the following sections concerning bail :

“ CARDINAL . ( CARDINAL ) Any accused person who is in custody for any crime or contravention may , on application , be granted temporary release from custody , upon giving sufficient security to appear at the proceedings at the appointed time and place .
CARDINAL . …
( CARDINAL ) The demand for bail shall be made by an application , a copy whereof shall be communicated to the Attorney - General on DATE , whenever it is made by –
( c ) persons accused of any crime punishable with DATE imprisonment ...
( CARDINAL ) The Attorney - General may , within DATE , by a note , oppose the application , stating the reasons for his opposition .
CARDINAL . ( CARDINAL ) ORG may not ex officio grant bail , unless it is applied for by the person charged or accused .
GPE ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance ( Chapter CARDINAL of the Laws of Malta ) provides :

“ Notwithstanding the provisions of LAW , and saving the extensions by the President of the term of the inquiry as provided in subsection ( CARDINAL ) of section CARDINAL of that Code , where the Attorney General has directed that a person charged with selling or dealing in a drug against this GPE or charged with promoting , constituting , organising or financing a conspiracy under paragraph ( f ) of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of section CARDINAL or with the offence mentioned in subsection ( CARDINAL ) of the said section CARDINAL is to be tried in ORG , such person shall be arraigned under arrest and ORG as a ORG shall conclude the inquiry within the term of DATE from the arraignment , and until the expiration of that term or , if the inquiry is concluded at an earlier date , until DATE , the person accused shall not be granted temporary release from custody , but at the end of DATE or such earlier date as aforesaid , the ORG may grant temporary release from custody in accordance with the provisions of that Code .

Provided that if the term of the inquiry is held in abeyance for the reason specified in paragraph ( c ) of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of section CARDINAL of LAW , the ORG may nonetheless grant temporary release from custody after the lapse of DATE from the arraignment . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON was arrested for drug - related offences . He applied for release relying on LAW and section CARDINAL of LAW and claiming that section CARDINAL of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance was in violation of the LAW . ORG refused to order his release . He subsequently lodged a constitutional application in FAC . On DATE ORG , relying on the GPE v. GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE of ORG ( to be published in Reports of Judgments and Decisions DATE ) , found section CARDINAL of the ordinance to be in violation of LAW . However , it did not order PERSON release . PERSON and the Attorney General appealed to ORG . ORG is expected to deliver its judgment on DATE . In the meanwhile PERSON was released on bail on DATE .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides :

“ Any Magistrate who , in a matter with his powers , fails or refuses to attend to a lawful complaint touching an unlawful detention , and any officer of ORG , who , on a similar complaint made to him , fails to prove that he reported the same to his superior authorities within TIME , shall , on conviction , be liable to imprisonment for a term from DATE . ”

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the police arrested PERSON for a breach of LAW . During his detention he became suspect of a serious offence concerning the public security of GPE . On DATE the applicant applied to ORG requesting that he should be either charged or released . On DATE ORG considered that it had the power under section CARDINAL ( currently section CARDINAL ) of LAW to attend to a lawful complaint touching on unlawful detention . It also found that the police had not brought Price before ORG within TIME as required by section CARDINAL ( currently section CARDINAL ) of LAW . As a result , the court ordered ORG ’s release .

CARDINAL . On DATE the First Hall of the Civil Court ordered PERSON to be detained for TIME for contempt of court . The detainee appealed under section CARDINAL of LAW . The Attorney General , with reference to ORG having invoked section CARDINAL of LAW , requested ORG to order ORG and the Commissioner of Police to bring ORG before the ORG and order either of them to set him free at once . According to the Attorney General , ORG ’s appeal had suspensive effect on the execution of the judgment and , as a result , his continued detention was illegal . ORG acceded to the Attorney General ’s request .

CARDINAL . PERSON later christened PERSON invoked section CARDINAL of LAW to challenge his prolonged and indefinite detention further to a removal order . He claimed that his detention , which had started in DATE , had been rendered illegal because of its length and indefinite duration . On DATE ORG ordered that the Attorney General be notified and , having heard his views , still on DATE , decided to reject the application .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected an application for release by PERSON . It observed :

“ As results from the records several applications have been filed , before this ORG and before ORG , so that the person charged may be released , which applications have always been dealt with expeditiously , which fact makes it manifest in the most glaring manner how superfluous and incomprehensible the first paragraph of the present application is , where it refers to LAW . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL subsection ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides as follows :

“ If in any proceedings in any court other than ORG , ORG , or ORG any question arises as to the contravention of any of the provisions of LAW , that court shall refer the question to ORG , ORG , unless in its opinion the raising of the question is merely frivolous or vexatious ; and that court shall give its decision on any question referred to it under this subsection and , subject to the provisions of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of this section , the court in which the question arose shall dispose of the question in accordance with that decision . ”
CARDINAL . By virtue of LAW of DATE the ORG became part of the law of GPE . Section CARDINAL subsection ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides :

“ If in any proceedings in any court other than ORG , ORG , or ORG any question arises as to the contravention of any of the provisions of the said sections DATE ( inclusive ) , that court shall refer the question to ORG , ORG , unless in its opinion the raising of the question is merely frivolous or vexatious ; and that court shall give its decision on any question referred to it under this subsection and , subject to the provisions of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of this section , the court in which the question arose shall dispose of the question in accordance with that decision . ”
